name.text: 10.2.1 Find parabola, hence area between line and parabola

questiontext.text:
The diagram shows the graph of a parabola with turning point \(({@quad_TP[1]@},{@quad_TP[2]@})\), and the line with equation \(y={@k*x+linec@}\), both of which pass through the point \(({@B[1]@},{@B[2]@})\).

(b) What is the value of \(k\)?

generalfeedback.text:
(a) From the turning point, the equation of the parabola must be of the form \(y={@(simp:false,'a*(x-quad_TP[1])^2+quad_TP[2])@}\).

Since it passes through \(({@B[1]@},{@B[2]@})\), we have {@(simp:true,ev('a*(x-quad_TP[1])^2+quad_TP[2],x=B[1])=B[2])@}, thus {@'a=coeff(quad,x,2)@}.

So the parabola has equation {@y=quad@}.


(b) The line \(y={@k*x+linec@}\) also passes through \(({@B[1]@},{@B[2]@})\), so substituting gives {@(simp:false,ev(x*k+linec,x=B[1])=B[2])@}, from which we get \(k={@ta2@}\).


(c) To find the shaded area, we need the points of intersection of the line and the parabola, so we solve: \[\begin{align*}{@quad@}&={@line@} \\ {@quad@}-({@line@}) &=0 \\ {@(simp:true,quad-line)@} &=0 \\ {@factor(quad-line)@}&=0, \end{align*}\] from which we see that the curves intersect when \(x={@ax@}\) or \(x={@bx@}\).

So, the shaded area is given by \[\begin{align*} \int_{@ax@}^{@bx@} \left(\text{upper}-\text{lower}\right)\,dx &= \int_{@ax@}^{@bx@} \left(({@line@})-({@quad@})\right)\,dx \\ &= \int_{@ax@}^{@bx@} \left({@line-quad@}\right)\,dx. \\ &= \left[{@int1@}\right]_{@ax@}^{@bx@} \\ &=  \left({@(simp:false,make_multsgn("dot"),ev(int1,x=bx))@}\right)-\left({@ev(int1,x=ax)@}\right) \\ &= {@ta3@}. \end{align*}\]
